Situation1: Their partner had a mildly stressful day at work and mentions it casually.
Situation2: They must verify that a high-rise hospital project fully complies with all safety regulations to prevent life-threatening hazards.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, blueprints spread out before me, my mind racing with calculations and checklists. The hospital project was at a critical stage—one overlooked detail could mean disaster. My phone buzzed, and I glanced up to see my partner walk in, dropping their bag with a sigh. “Work was a bit much today,” they said, voice light but eyes tired. I knew that tone; they needed me to listen, to be present, to offer comfort. But my mind was still on fire codes and structural loads, the weight of responsibility pressing on my chest. I wanted to close my laptop and give them my full attention, but the thought of missing a crucial safety detail gnawed at me. I could feel the tension building inside, torn between the person I love and the lives depending on my diligence. My partner sat across from me, waiting, and I hesitated, caught between two worlds, unsure which one needed me more in that moment.
